unnormalised: Social Media & Influencer Marketing: Virality Trends
normalised: social media and influencer marketing: virality trends

unnormalised: What's trending, yaar? The virality game is changing faster than Delhi's weather! Remember the "Rasode Mein Kaun Tha?" craze? That was peak 2020. Now, it's all about reels with catchy Bollywood remixes and relatable content.
normalised: what is trending, yaar? the virality game is changing faster than delhi's weather! remember the "rasode mein kaun tha?" craze? that was peak two thousand and twenty. now, it is all about reels with catchy bollywood remixes and relatable content.

unnormalised: Experts at IIT-Bombay are studying these trends, trying to crack the code. Apparently, short-form video content with strong emotional hooks is king. Think stories about the struggle of getting chai in Mumbai's local trains or a mother's heartfelt message during Diwali.
normalised: experts at I I T-bombay are studying these trends, trying to crack the code. apparently, short-form video content with strong emotional hooks is king. think stories about the struggle of getting chai in mumbai's local trains or a mother's heartfelt message during diwali.

unnormalised: But hereâ€™s the catch: what goes viral today, might be forgotten by tomorrow. Brands are struggling to keep up. Influencers like Prajakta Koli are leading the way, creating authentic, long-lasting connections.
normalised: but here is the catch: what goes viral today, might be forgotten by tomorrow. brands are struggling to keep up. influencers like prajakta koli are leading the way, creating authentic, long-lasting connections.

unnormalised: On October 26, 2023, at 14:30 hrs, a webinar discussed "The Half-Life of Virality." The key takeaway? Engage genuinely, and don't force it. Also, remember that trend started on 01/01/2024, with "Desi-ghee-challenge"? Focus on long-term brand building, not just that one viral moment. Your brand is not made of Maggi that's to cook in 2 minutes. Even Shah Rukh Khan took time to become "King Khan!"
normalised: on october twenty sixth, two thousand and twenty three, at fourteen thirty hours, a webinar discussed "the half-life of virality." the key takeaway? engage genuinely, and don't force it. also, remember that trend started on first january two thousand and twenty four, with "desi-ghee-challenge"? focus on long-term brand building, not just that one viral moment. your brand is not made of maggi that is to cook in two minutes. even shah rukh khan took time to become "king khan!"
